attachments.title: On the Budyko-Sellers energy balance climate model with ice line coupling
attachments.text: Over 40 years ago, M. Budyko and W. Sellers independently introduced low-order climate models that continue to play an important role in the mathematical modeling of climate. Each model has one spatial variable, and each was introduced to investigate the role ice-albedo feedback plays in influencing surface temperature. This paper serves in part as a tutorial on the Budyko-Sellers model, with particular focus placed on the coupling of this model with an ice sheet that is allowed to respond to changes in temperature, as introduced in recent work by E. Widiasih. We review known results regarding the dynamics of this coupled model, with both continuous (``Sellers-type") and discontinuous (``Budyko-type") equations. We also introduce two new Budyko-type models that are highly effective in modeling the extreme glacial events of the Neoproterozoic Era. We prove in each case the existence of a stable equilibrium solution for which the ice sheet edge rests in tropical latitudes. Mathematical tools used in the analysis include geometric singular perturbation theory and Filippov's theory of differential inclusions.

messages.text:
<@US5RA4FK4> Just some personal thoughts for why Julia > C/C++/Fortran/Python from using Julia for the past ~2 years for HPC climate work (mostly Oceananigans.jl development which is separate from ClimateMachine.jl but still under the CliMA project):
1. Pure Julia loop-based code can be fast, easy-to-read, and executes readily on CPUs (multithreaded) and GPUs with KernelAbstractions.jl. Possible counter-example could be Python + Numba but I think to get maximum efficiency you still need to write some low-level code in C/Cython?
2. Pure Julia code means you can interface with a rapidly-growing scientific machine learning software stack: Flux.jl for machine learning, DifferentialEquations.jl for time stepping and sensitivity analysis, Turing.jl for Bayesian inference and uncertainty quantification, etc. and they work well together so Flux.jl + DifferentialEquations.jl = neural differential equations can be trained and embedded in your Julia climate model.
3. Script-based approach to simulation setup allows for very flexible setups that would either be very complicated to setup with Fortran models + namelist files. This is more a criticism of rigid namelist files though.
4. Julia is functional so you can pass around functions, use them to specify boundary conditions, forcing functions, etc. which makes scripts look more like math and easier to read. Similar setups in Fortran + namelists can be quite painful: e.g. generate arrays in MATLAB/Python, dump binary data, tell Fortran model to read binary file via namelist.
5. It seems to be much easier to engage and excite new users and contributors with Julia as opposed to Fortran and C/C++. New young students and postdocs seem more likely to learn and use high-level languages like Julia/Python rather than C/C++/Fortran.
6. Some C/C++/Fortran models are a complete pain to set up and compile, which can be a high barrier for new users. Julia + CUDA + MPI setup hasn't failed on me yet (it's really plug and play) and it's getting better (e.g. CUDA.jl now downloads and installs the CUDA library for you).
These are just (personal) general thoughts/reasons arguing for climate modeling in Julia. For a modeling center to undertake a complete rewrite of an existing model is probably very much dependent on their situation and their team's willingness to learn/embrace a new programming language.

Similar setups in Fortran + namelists can be quite painful: e.g. generate arrays in MATLAB/Python, dump binary data, tell Fortran model to read binary file via namelist.

It would be useful for Clima as well as other people that want to promote Julia in their workspaces if you, or these people, can share _specific complains_. Or equivalently, concrete arguments on why would they prefer the old. And of course I'm personally interested only in the objective arguments (because "oh I've coded in Fortran for 10 years, its easier for me to read" is a rather subjective argument).

When I switched from C to Python and then from Python to Julia, I had a lot of complains. But turns out, the only objective ones I had were the lack of documentation and googlability. I am wondering what complains an "older generation" of programmers has, given that they have expertise that I never achieved.

messages.text: I think the big one is iteration time.  Clima and ESM's in general are big projects and so startup time really can hurt the workflow of scientists.  Fortran can aggressively cache compiled code so often you can re-compile a fortran model with your changes and re-run faster than it takes the Julia model to precompile during startup.   More aggressive code caching will obv. help with this along with compiler improvements so this is getting addressed over time.  This impacts the diagnostics side as well, it seems like still  mostly python + some julia there until the package ecosystem can catch up (for GCM diagnostics).

messages.text: re: development time. Once I have compiled an existing module, i.e. called it with `using Module`, any further change I do, which can include altering several functions and adding several new ones over the course of a session, is instant, no need to recompile. I simply press Ctrl+Enter in Juno in the function I've just coded, I don't even have to do a setup for it. For me this feels like a gift from the gods :smile:  Because everything remains in memory. I don't close a Julia session and then reopen it (which is what would happen in Fortran, given that it is not dynamic). This allows me to develop code _interactively_, a feature that by itself is worth coding in a higher level language, and in fact the entire reason the famous "2 language problem" exists in the first place.

attachments.text: In climatology, the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP) is a collaborative framework designed to improve knowledge of climate change, being the analog of Atmospheric Model Intercomparison Project (AMIP) for global coupled ocean-atmosphere general circulation models (GCMs). It was organized in 1995 by the Working Group on Coupled Modelling (WGCM) of the World Climate Research Programme’s (WCRP). It is developed in phases to foster the climate model improvements but also to support national and international assessments of climate change.

messages.text: Do energy balance models tend to underestimate the climate sensitivity?

For 0D energy balance models the climate sensitivity is essentially an input parameter, as it turns out to be a direct function of input parameters like surface albedo and effective emissivity and their functional forms.
